review.title: Geometric features for voxel-based surface recognition
review.abstract: We introduce a library of geometric voxel features for CAD surface recognition/retrieval tasks. Our features include local versions of the intrinsic volumes (the usual 3D volume, surface area, integrated mean and Gaussian curvature) and a few closely related quantities. We also compute Haar wavelet and statistical distribution features by aggregating raw voxel features. We apply our features to object classification on the ESB data set and demonstrate accurate results with a small number of shallow decision trees.

metadata.title: Geometric features for voxel-based surface recognition

sections.text: Keywords: CAD surface recognition and query, feature vector, integral geometry, voxel, decision tree, hair wavelet, engineering shape benchmark

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, the time has come for us to be able to go to a place where we can go to a place where we can go to a place where we can go to a place where we can move.

sections.heading: 3 Feature aggregation
sections.text: At high resolutions, the local features calculated in voxels, as described above, can lead to an excessively detailed description of the surface. A classifier trained in such a description is likely to greatly overestimate it. One way to counteract this is to use a classification algorithm with mechanisms to prevent over-training - e.g. a convent, since it uses weight sharing. Another possibility is to transform the initial "raw" voxel characteristics directly into some more suitable, "aggregated" characteristics. [11] The available grid-like structure of raw voxel representation is indispensable for some aggregation strategies. An example of such aggregation is a wavelength transformation of voxel data. We consider the simplest case of − − − n − statistical characteristics [11]. Suppose that a scalar voxel characteristic with a resolution of N = 2W is weighted W, the entire W W is weighted as − 2W where W is W − W.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We have performed a series of classification errors simply as a fraction of the tests that measure the actual efficiency of the various strategies. [15] This collection consists of 866 mechanical parts that are divided into 3 "superclasses." [17] There are 45 fine classes in their entirety (hereinafter simply referred to as classes), in particular each superclass contains a different class for objects that cannot easily be assigned to other classes of this superclass. See Fig. 4 for some examples of ESB objects. We have divided the collection into a training group of 675 objects and a test set of 191 objects that can be used in all experiments.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced and studied several voxel features inspired by integral geometry, as well as some more complex (hair and statistical) features derived from it. We have tested our features on the task of classifying ESB CAD models with gradient-enhanced trees and observed reasonably good performance. Our framework has allowed us to compare the efficiency of different features and different resolutions at which they are evaluated. In particular, we have found that within this framework the best ESB classification results were obtained with very flat, depth-2 trees, which favored high-resolution statistical features as well as some global characteristics such as the total integals of Gaussian and mean curvature. Generating complex features for high-resolution voxelization is a relatively complex and time-consuming task, so there is a certain tradeoff in classification between the use of complex features with simple predictive features (such as applied in our predictive models and in deep constellations).

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: The author thanks Ermek Kapushev, Alexandr Notchenko and Evgeny Burnaev for many interesting conversations.

In 3D, there are four intrinsic volumes: the usual 3D volume, the surface area, and the integrated mean and Gaussian curvatures of the surface [22].
The intrinsic volumes are known to generally play a major role in practical pattern recognition problems [19,24].

The central general result in integral geometry, Hadwiger’s theorem, states that any additive, Euclidean invariant functional on d-dimensional bodies that is Hausdorffcontinuous on the set of convex bodies is a linear combination of the d + 1 intrinsic volumes (in particular, the four aforementioned volumes in the 3D case) [6, 12,16].

We have performed a series of classification experiments with the ESB (Engineering Shape Benchmark, [15]) collection of CAD models.
Our classifiers are ensembles of gradient boosted trees trained using the XGBoost library [7].

While it is common to train voxelization-based classifiers with neural networks [10, 26], XGBoost has allowed us to easily mix raw and aggregated features as well as features on different length scales, and examine their relative effect and the complexity of the resulting classifiers.

Our features include local versions of the intrinsic volumes (the usual 3D volume, surface area, integrated mean and Gaussian curvature) and a few closely related quantities.
